title: Chinese Government provides CFA 3.9 billion grant for Potable Water Supply in Three North Brazzaville Neighborhoods Project
description: In 2003, the Chinese Government provided a grant worth CFA 3.9 billion to the Government of the Republic of Congo for the Potable Water Supply in Three North Brazzaville Neighborhoods Project. This project involved the installation of a water supply system — consisting of three water pump stations, a 111 meter borehole, a 103 meter borehole, a 97 meter borehole, and a 53 km water pipeline — in three districts in North Brazzaville: Nkombo, Massengo and Moukondo. The ultimate goal of the project was to increase access to potable drinking water.   Beijing Uni-Construction Company (BUCC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Construction started on August 15, 2003, and was completed on August 1, 2005.
staff_comments: The Chinese project name is 布拉柴维尔市北部供水工程. The French project title is l’Alimentation en Eau potable dans trois quartiers du Nord de Brazzaville or Projet d'adduction d'eau dans les quartiers périphériques.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides CFA 3.9 billion grant for Potable Water Supply in Three North Brazzaville Neighborhoods Project

# Description
In 2003, the Chinese Government provided a grant worth CFA 3.9 billion to the Government of the Republic of Congo for the Potable Water Supply in Three North Brazzaville Neighborhoods Project. This project involved the installation of a water supply system — consisting of three water pump stations, a 111 meter borehole, a 103 meter borehole, a 97 meter borehole, and a 53 km water pipeline — in three districts in North Brazzaville: Nkombo, Massengo and Moukondo. The ultimate goal of the project was to increase access to potable drinking water.   Beijing Uni-Construction Company (BUCC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Construction started on August 15, 2003, and was completed on August 1, 2005.
justification: Project focuses on water supply infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Installation of water supply system including pump stations, boreholes, and pipelines for potable water access

title: Chinese Government dispatches 17th medical team to Makélékélé Reference Hospital and Talangaï Hospital
description: Since 1967, the Chinese Government has been dispatching medical teams to the Republic of Congo every two years. Tianjin City is responsible for sending the teams. On August 26, 2002, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Congo signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 17th Chinese medical team to the Republic of Congo  [第17批援刚（布）医疗队].   The 23-member team was stationed at Makélékélé Reference Hospital (Hôpital de Makélékélé) and Talangaï Hospital (Hôpital De Talangaï) in the capital city of Brazzaville. It completed its term of service between December 2002 and December 20, 2004.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

# Description

The 23-member team was stationed at Makélékélé Reference Hospital (Hôpital de Makélékélé) and Talangaï Hospital (Hôpital De Talangaï) in the capital city of Brazzaville. It completed its term of service between December 2002 and December 20, 2004.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million grant for Ministry of Foreign Affairs Headquarters Construction Project
description: In January 2003, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 20 million grant to the Republic of Congo for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Headquarters Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a headquarters building for the Republic of Congo’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the capital city of Brazzaville. The six-story building includes a reception hall, conference rooms, offices, and an auditorium. It is a comprehensive office building that is used to receive government officials from Africa and other regions for meetings and visits.    The building was co-financed with the Republic of Congo, and its total cost was $19 million.  Beijing Uni-Construction Company (BUCC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction of the project began in 2003 and it was completed on March 27, 2008.  The construction of a fountain outside the building was completed in September 2011.
staff_comments: The French project title is l'immeuble du ministère des Affaires étrangères or le siège du ministère des Affaires étrangères. The Chinese project title is 刚果（布）外交部大楼.
combined_text:

GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million grant for Ministry of Foreign Affairs Headquarters Construction Project

# Description
In January 2003, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 20 million grant to the Republic of Congo for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Headquarters Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a headquarters building for the Republic of Congo’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the capital city of Brazzaville. The six-story building includes a reception hall, conference rooms, offices, and an auditorium. It is a comprehensive office building that is used to receive government officials from Africa and other regions for meetings and visits.    The building was co-financed with the Republic of Congo, and its total cost was $19 million.  Beijing Uni-Construction Company (BUCC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction of the project began in 2003 and it was completed on March 27, 2008.  The construction of a fountain outside the building was completed in September 2011.
justification: Project is focused on government office building construction without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of Ministry of Foreign Affairs headquarters building, includes offices and meeting spaces, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Djoué Radio Station Equipment Upgrading and Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#72848, #72850)
description: In 2003, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided a grant to the Government of the Republic of Congo for the Djoué Radio Station Equipment Upgrading and Rehabilitation Project. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. These grant proceeds were drawn at least in part from a $2.8 million grant agreement that the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed in January 2003.   The project involved the supply, installation and commissioning of one shortwave radio launching station, two 50KW shortwave radio transmitters, 3 antenna feeders, antenna exchange switches, power distribution equipment, and air conditioning equipment. China Radio and Television International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (CRTV) was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed on February 28, 2003. It passed a final MOFCOM inspection on March 17, 2003. It was officially handed over to the Congolese authorities in August 2003.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援刚果朱埃广播电台设备更新和大修项目 or 刚果（布）朱埃电台工程. The French project tittle is la réhabilitation d'un centre-émetteur du Djoué. The project is linked with Phase 4 of Djoué Radio Station Technical Cooperation Project (See Project ID#72848), and Phase 5 of Djoué Radio Station Technical Cooperation Project (See Project ID#72850).

China Radio and Television International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (CRTV) was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed on February 28, 2003. justification: Project focuses on communications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Radio station equipment upgrading and rehabilitation, communications sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides NZD 4.8 million grant for Courthouse Construction Project (linked to #69560)
description: In October 2003, the Cook Islands Government announced that the Chinese Government had agreed to provide a grant for the Courthouse Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly committed NZ$4,800,000 (US$6 million) of total grant funding for the project. The purpose of the project was to construct a courthouse building for the Ministry of Justice in Avarua (exact locational coordinates: -21.207251, -159.774899). China Civil Engineering Construction (CCECC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction commenced on October 29, 2003 and approximately 85 Chinese workers were involved during the construction phase.   The courthouse was opened for use on its scheduled completion date (November 15, 2004). Father Tony Dunn, a Catholic priest, called for a boycott of the courthouse on the eve of its formal opening, warning of a ‘hidden Chinese foreign policy’ in the Pacific. The sponsor (China’s Ministry of Commerce) then conducted an on-site, post-project inspection in November 2007 and December 2007. Cook Islands Secretary of Justice Mark Short announced in June 2010 that the courthouse was "only six years old [but] starting to fall apart’. He said that the courthouse was not built to suit a tropical climate – when it rained, the front steps were dangerously slippery and parts of the office would flood.    Also, there were cracks in the marble walls and the ventilation and air-conditioning system was poorly designed. Electrical services reportedly failed from the start, requiring expensive repairs by local contractors. According to Reuters, a 'make-shift pen was built outside the courthouse because the [jail] cells beneath it ran out of oxygen if occupied for more than two hours'. The Chinese Government eventually agreed to provide a grant to repair the courthouse and several other government buildings in 2017 (as captured via linked Project ID#69560). According to Cook Islands Finance Minister Mark Brown, it was a major repair job because China’s previous construction work was ‘substandard’.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Ministry of Justice Building Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 库克群岛高法大楼 or 库克群岛高等法院大楼项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides NZD 4.8 million grant for Courthouse Construction Project (linked to #69560)

# Description
In October 2003, the Cook Islands Government announced that the Chinese Government had agreed to provide a grant for the Courthouse Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly committed NZ$4,800,000 (US$6 million) of total grant funding for the project. The purpose of the project was to construct a courthouse building for the Ministry of Justice in Avarua (exact locational coordinates: -21.207251, -159.774899). China Civil Engineering Construction (CCECC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction commenced on October 29, 2003 and approximately 85 Chinese workers were involved during the construction phase.   The courthouse was opened for use on its scheduled completion date (November 15, 2004). Father Tony Dunn, a Catholic priest, called for a boycott of the courthouse on the eve of its formal opening, warning of a ‘hidden Chinese foreign policy’ in the Pacific. The sponsor (China’s Ministry of Commerce) then conducted an on-site, post-project inspection in November 2007 and December 2007. Cook Islands Secretary of Justice Mark Short announced in June 2010 that the courthouse was "only six years old [but] starting to fall apart’. He said that the courthouse was not built to suit a tropical climate – when it rained, the front steps were dangerously slippery and parts of the office would flood.    Also, there were cracks in the marble walls and the ventilation and air-conditioning system was poorly designed. Electrical services reportedly failed from the start, requiring expensive repairs by local contractors. According to Reuters, a 'make-shift pen was built outside the courthouse because the [jail] cells beneath it ran out of oxygen if occupied for more than two hours'. The Chinese Government eventually agreed to provide a grant to repair the courthouse and several other government buildings in 2017 (as captured via linked Project ID#69560). According to Cook Islands Finance Minister Mark Brown, it was a major repair job because China’s previous construction work was ‘substandard’.
justification: Project involves construction of a courthouse, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Courthouse construction, government building, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China donates 5 Mercedes-Benz vehicles to Cote d'Ivoire
description: On 15 April 2003, the Chinese Ambassador officially donated five Mercedes-Benz Atego 2528 vehicles to the Government of Cote d'lvoire. The value of this donation is unknown.

title: Chinese Government provides $6 million USD grant to improve Cuba education
description: On 15 January 2003, the governments of Cuba and China signed an agreement for Economic and Technical Cooperation, under which China will provide a $6 million USD grant for the improvement of Cuba's education sector. Chinese Foreign Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng and Cuban Interior Minister Ricardo Cabrisas signed the agreement at the end of a joint economic and commercial session between the two countries. The agreement will further strengthen bilateral ties.
staff_comments: No new sources that indicate that the money was disbursed even though it probably was given the subject matter.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides $6 million USD grant to improve Cuba education

# Description
On 15 January 2003, the governments of Cuba and China signed an agreement for Economic and Technical Cooperation, under which China will provide a $6 million USD grant for the improvement of Cuba's education sector. Chinese Foreign Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng and Cuban Interior Minister Ricardo Cabrisas signed the agreement at the end of a joint economic and commercial session between the two countries. The agreement will further strengthen bilateral ties.
justification: Project focuses on education sector improvement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: $6 million USD grant for education sector improvement, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 472,167 tons of crude oil to North Korea in 2003
description: In 2003, the Chinese Government donated approximately 472,167 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 472,167 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,460,984.11 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($107,567,386.13), AidData has taken the average price ($31.08) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2003 and multiplied it by 3,460,984.11 barrels of oil.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. According to one academic source see《对朝援助——中国外援的缩影》, the monetary value of this donation was $76.46 million. However, for consistency with the method of valuing crude oil donations used in other project records (e.g., Project ID#63155, Project ID#63154, and Project ID#63152), AidData relies on the $107,567,386.13 estimate using international pricing.2. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 472,167 tons of crude oil to North Korea in 2003

# Description
In 2003, the Chinese Government donated approximately 472,167 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 472,167 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,460,984.11 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($107,567,386.13), AidData has taken the average price ($31.08) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2003 and multiplied it by 3,460,984.11 barrels of oil.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: Donation of crude oil directly supports fossil fuel dependency and consumption
evidence: 472,167 tons of crude oil donated, processed at North Korea's refinery for government, military, and industrial use

title: Chinese Government donates 10,000 tons of diesel oil in 2003 (Linked to Project ID#73424, #73425, #73426)
description: In July 2003, the Chinese Government decided to donate 10,000 tons of diesel oil to North Korea, according to the KCNA. This donation was verified by the Republic of Korea's Ministry of Unification. 10,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 73,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($2,278,164), AidData takes the average price ($31.08) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) Crude Oil in 2003 and multiplies it by 73,000 barrels of oil.
staff_comments: This project is linked to other diesel oil donations captured in Project ID#73424, #73425, #73426.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government donates spare parts worth RMB 40 million for O&M of Pyongyang Metro, 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant, Xingnan Fertilizer Plant, and Ponghwa Chemical Factory in 2003
description: In 2003, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) agreed to provide an RMB 40 million grant to the North Korean Government for the provision of spare parts to support the operations and maintenance (O&M) of the Pyongyang Metro, 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant, Xingnan Fertilizer Plant, and the Ponghwa Chemical Factory. China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corp. Ltd. (COMPLANT or 中成进出口股份有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. MOFCOM issued it an RMB 40 million contract in 2003. AidData assumes that this project was completed since a follow-on project was approved in 2004 (as captured via Project ID#73832). However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unknown.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 年度向朝鲜提供零配件项目. Xingnan Fertilizer Plant is also known as the Hungnam Fertilizer Complex or 흥남비료연합기업소. Ponghwa Chemical Factory is also known as the Fenghuo Chemical Plant or 朝鲜烽火化工厂.2. The Pyongyang Metro was the first modern urban rail project built with Chinese aid. It was completed in 1975. The Ponghwa Chemical Factory was also constructed with Chinese aid. It was put into operation in September 1978. The factory uses crude oil transported by two pipelines between China and Sinuihi. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea’s government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.3. This is an O&M project supported via recurring grants from MOFCOM between 2001 and 2008. However, AidData was not able to identify any further evidence of financial support from MOFCOM after 2008. As such, no additional MOFCOM grants are recorded after 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Government donates spare parts worth RMB 40 million for O&M of Pyongyang Metro, 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant, Xingnan Fertilizer Plant, and Ponghwa Chemical Factory in 2003

# Description
In 2003, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) agreed to provide an RMB 40 million grant to the North Korean Government for the provision of spare parts to support the operations and maintenance (O&M) of the Pyongyang Metro, 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant, Xingnan Fertilizer Plant, and the Ponghwa Chemical Factory. China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corp. Ltd. (COMPLANT or 中成进出口股份有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. MOFCOM issued it an RMB 40 million contract in 2003. AidData assumes that this project was completed since a follow-on project was approved in 2004 (as captured via Project ID#73832). However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unknown.
justification: Primary focus is supporting a coal-fired power plant, which is a high-emission energy source, along with other industrial facilities
evidence: 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant explicitly mentioned as a beneficiary of the spare parts donation
